[h1]Where can I get a real life portal gun?[/h1]

This is going to be one of my more shorter reviews as there isn't really much to say considering that I've played and enjoyed Portal 2. Even though I enjoyed the sequel more, I found this one enjoyable as well. It's exactly as I would have expected it to be with some exceptions. This one was nice and short, which is nice considering that is the gameplay length I'm looking for right now. Without spoiling anything, the ending was a little more "emotional" than I expected it to be. You'll see what I mean.

Rating: [b]4 out of 5.[/b]

Portal. A genuinely interesting game that relies, well you know, portals to reach an objective. Portal is a game that wants you to think outside the box and makes you want to think out on how you're going to get there. Now I have to admit, the story is so short, you can probably complete it in like 5 hours or about 40 minutes if you're speedrunning. The antagonist is very interesting once you fight it. The ending credits were amazing, the song Still Alive was a great song and humorous too.
Hope this review helped.

The First installation of my absolute favourite game series.

Portal is a top of the list, must have for everyone. This game is more than just a Puzzle, it's an experience.
There is a damn good reason why I have played this more times than I can count. I would without hesitation play it again.

The game cannot be summed up by a review. The only way for you to understand the masterpiece that is Portal is to play it yourself.

GLaDOSï¼Œå”±æ­Œï¼Œå¥½å¬
Great game.

Portal 1 is a nearly perfect puzzle game with witty humor, tough puzzles, and a sense of loneliness that the game consistently is throwing at you. 

The game puts you in the long fall boots of Chell, a test subject in the labs of Aperture Labratories. Through out the game, GLaDOS, an AI, is constantly talking to you through the intercoms, sometimes discouraging you, and other times being a super sarcastic nugget. Listening to GLaDOS speak makes you want to finish the game because of how you want to prove her wrong the whole time. 

The game progresses through test chambers, the true meat of the game. All of these test chambers are made to make you test you're own intelligence with the science of portals through the usage of the Portal Gun, a device that can shoot two portals on walls for you to go through. This is used super creatively through out the game, forcing you to really think about what walls you can shoot to get through. It doesn't work on all walls. It brings out ideas of momentum, puzzle solving, and enemy defeating that no other game can come close to replicating.

The game's atmosphere is creepy and eery, as there are windows with chairs and computers in every level, as if someone is watching you. The loneliness can make you go paranoid, making the strive to go through the game all the more desired. The music is calm, yet unsettling, making the few moments when music starts blaring out highlight moments, similar to what Half-Life did. 

Some of the flaws here are the the glitchiness of the game. Sometimes the game feels a little bit glitchy, but they're no game breakers. Other than that, this game is almost perfect. It could've been a bit longer. 

This game is a lot of fun to play through multiple times. Portal is a solid 9.5/10 
A solid game worth your time.

Rather short game compared to Portal 2, which is the more famous sequel spawned from this game. If you played Portal 2 first as I have, be prepared to perform simpler puzzles that rely more on gaining speed to do aerial jumps and such. That said, I cannot understate how much fun it was listening to GlaDOS throughout this whole game. She really brightens this whole game to another level that I can appreciate.
